newsitem.title: KYRGYZSTAN: FEATURE - Kyrgyz drug squad, a long way from Miami Vice.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - Kyrgyz drug squad, a long way from Miami Vice.

text.p: The drug squad in this Central Asian country call him "Papa" because they respect him like a father.
Timur Timurbekov, a senior detective, is like an older, less glamorous version of Sonny Crockett -- the stylish, freewheeling character in the U.S. television series "Miami Vice".
As usual, television police have little to do with reality. And reality in Kyrgyzstan is as far removed as you can get from flashing neon lights and pulsating background music.

Timur, 41, leads a team of professionals in the frontline of a battle to stem a tide of opium from Afghanistan that is feeding crime, especially organised crime, in this former Soviet republic, and threatening Russia and Europe.

The entire police force here is suffering from a chronic cash shortage. Salaries have not been paid for two or three months. In the circumstances, it is remarkable that the anti-drug fighters having any success at all.

"Drug prices are rising, so this means that some measures are being taken," said Timur Issakov, deputy head of the Kyrgyz Interior Ministry's anti-drug department. "At the moment, the situation is under control.
"But if we talk about equipment, it's just a joke," he sighed.

Only a few senior officers enjoy the luxury of a car, so there are no high-speed car chases through the not so mean streets of Kara-Bolta, about 60 km (40 miles) northwest of the capital Bishkek, where horses and carts are a common sight.
Police radios are also a rare luxury, and there are no closed frequencies. Anyone can listen in, including the increasingly sophisticated crime syndicates involved in the lucrative drug business.
In Kara-Bolta, a town of about 70,000 best known for its vodka, Timur lives in a modest three-room flat with his wife and three children.
His working clothes -- track suit trousers, T-shirt and worn sneakers -- are classic Soviet-style casual wear. No designer jackets or sunglasses.
But when Timur goes on a raid he carries it out with a panache that would do Miami Vice proud. "You'll probably go down for 15 years," he told one suspected dealer.

"No, please, I've got a young kid," the man pleaded. In front of him Timur clapped handcuffs onto two young men suspected of buying opium, several doses of which lay on the kitchen table next to a half-eaten watermelon.
The two bleary-eyed men admitted that they were addicts. Timur held up their arms and showed the injection marks.
"Look at him. You might think he was a sportsman," said the grey-haired detective. "And this one, he could be a doctor," he added, turning to the other.
There was another man with a bit-part in this drama, an odd-looking character in a striped suit and sunglasses, but his role was unclear.
"I was just standing by the car and they brought me in here," he said. Timur was unconvinced but didn't arrest him.
On the whole, he was sympathetic. He understood that drug addiction was more of an illness than a crime. "I would sometimes like to release them. I think about the children."
He said Kyrgyzstan's economic problems, including unemployment, had contributed to an increase in drug use and trafficking. "If they had jobs, they would not do this," he said.
Oleg, 26, one of those arrested by Timur's team, said he started taking drugs when he was 17. "I tried hashish and liked it. Now I take opium every day, once a day."

He was unemployed and depended on his wife for cash to pay for his habit. A typical dose of opium costs about 20-40 som ($1.50-3.50) -- a sizeable amount in a country where the average monthly wage is only about $50.
Most addicts "shoot up" every day, some three times a day.
Oleg's wife, perhaps expecting the inevitable, showed surprisingly little emotion when she arrived later and watched him being led away.
Sergei, 22, the second addict, was in a similar position, unemployed and using drugs for three months, often paid for by his wife.

Timur's partner, Agzam, gathered the evidence against the two men in a polythene bag. A stocky close-cropped bull of a man, with a pistol tucked inside his belt, he said nothing and let Timur do the talking.
Agzam was one of the few members of the 180-man drug squad here carrying a gun.
Kyrgyzstan, one of the poorest former Soviet republics, cannot afford to issue weapons to all its policemen.
